#Text=Beatriz de Padilla
#Text=Beatriz de Padilla ( b. 1620 's ) was a Mexican-born Morisco woman who rose from slavery to property ownership .
#Text=Her legal battles and persecution by the Spanish Inquisition gained her notability during her lifetime .
#Text=Born in Mexico after 1620 , de Padilla was the daughter of Lorenzo de Padilla , a Spaniard and Cecilia de Alvarado , a mulatta slave and later servant in Lagos , Guadalajara , Mexico .
#Text=De Padilla was originally a slave owned by the priest Francisco Perez Rubin , but he emancipated her do to her exemplary service . [ 1 ]
#Text=Caste system
#Text=During de Padilla 's life , New Spain followed a caste system that categorized people based on the amount of " pure blood " or Spanish blood . [ 2 ]

column1: #Text=This system limited the already restricted social mobility of non-Spaniard races and those who possessed a lesser amount of Spanish blood were segregated from jobs , were banned from carrying arms , had to live with their masters and could not be in large groups . [ 3 ]
#Text=As one of de Padilla 's parents was a mulatta slave and possessed African blood , de Padilla was not considered a Spaniard and lived as a slave .
#Text=Despite being categorized as a non-Spaniard under the caste system , de Padilla would have been able to enjoy some of the flexibility that came with being considered a non-Spanish woman .
#Text=Caste females did not have to adhere to the same social regulations as " pure blood " Spanish women .

#Text=Spanish colonial society did not believe that caste females had any honor to keep or defend , whereas Spanish women were expected to adhere to purity standards - however this did not stop some from seeing caste females ' behaviors as a threat to Christian order and morality . [ 4 ] [ 5 ] . [ 6 ]
#Text=Legal issues
#Text=According to sources , De Padilla took many lovers , some of whom were of high standing . [ 7 ]
#Text=As a consequence , she was frequently accused by authorities immoral behaviors and violating the expected gender roles of Spanish/Christian women .
#Text=De Padilla was also accused of mistreating her slaves and servants .
#Text=In one instance , one of de Padilla 's servants , Catalina Ia Garay , accused her of burning her with hot grease and branding her .
#Text=These claims were unfounded , but De Padilla confessed to them . [ 8 ]
#Text=De Padilla was targeted by the Spanish Inquisition for her relationship with Diego Ortiz Saavedra , a wealthy priest .
#Text=Ortiz Saavedra had fathered an illlegitimate child with de Padilla .
#Text=Before he died , he announced that he was leaving his belongings to de Padilla and the child .
#Text=As a result , his family denounced her to the Inquisition . [ 4 ]
#Text=At the hearings , witnesses claimed that de Padilla had poisoned Ortiz Saavedra by placing her menstrual blood in his bathwater .
#Text=They also claimed that she caused him to lose his sanity before his death . [ 9 ]
#Text=The Inquisition brought in La Garay as a witness .
#Text=She repeated her earlier accusations and added more of them .
#Text=However , they were later disproved . [ 4 ]
#Text=In her defense , De Padilla stated that Ortiz Saavedra had loved her and that his family had falsified the claims to take her inheritance .
#Text=The Inquisition exonerated and released de Padilla .
#Text=She returned to Lago and resumed a relationship with a former lover , the lord mayor of Juchipila , Don Diego de las Marinas . [ 4 ]
